Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Information Mechanisms and Robust Stabilization of Nonlinear, Stochastic Transportation Networks

Yanfeng Ouyang, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

The research objective of the proposed efforts is to reveal (i) why similar system-level instability problems arise in a variety of complex transportation networks (e.g., car-following traffic and logistics supply chains) and (ii) how to provide and utilize information to improve system stability and collective network behavior. This research will develop a unified framework where the dynamics of different networks are encompassed by overarching mathematical models to evaluate network behaviors and system characteristics. Robust stability analysis tools, stability conditions, and stabilization strategies that account for various nonlinear, stochastic behavioral and operational factors will be created to enrich the understanding of how information provision and utilization may improve network behavior. This work has the potential to bring out commonalities from seemingly unrelated network systems, and integrate their respective modeling approaches to enhance the methodological applicability within different domains.

The proposed research project is expected to provide significant managerial insights and control strategies that hold the promise of stabilizing and improving operations of a variety of transportation networks, which will have a profound impact on the transportation and freight logistics industry with strong economical and societal implications (e.g., reducing congestion and resource consumption). The new integrated analysis framework created through this project will lay a novel foundation for solutions to a wide range of complex problems in diverse scientific fields. This project will lead to new educational practices by the creation, integration, and dissemination of innovative teaching materials such as Internet-based interactive simulation tools. Outreach efforts will continue to be conducted to involve and attract students from underrepresented groups and to stimulate research interests in transportation networks among public and private industry sectors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project has developed mathematical models and computational tools that enrich our understanding of instability, inefficiency, and unreliability problems in nonlinear and stochastic transportation networks. The research outcomes reveal (i) why similar system-level instability problems arise in a variety of complex transportation networks (e.g., car-following traffic and logistics supply chains) and (ii) how to provide and utilize information to improve system stability and collective network behavior. Four Ph.D. students have worked (partially) on this project at the University of Illinois, through which they developed unified modeling frameworks where the dynamics of different networks are encompassed by overarching mathematical models to evaluate network behaviors and system characteristics. This work brings out commonalities from seemingly unrelated network systems, and integrates their respective modeling approaches to enhance the methodological applicability within different domains. Particular focus has been cast on supply chain networks with nonlinear reordering policies, and stop-and-go traffic under nonlinear/stochastic car-following laws. A set of new methodologies are also developed to improve planning and resource allocation in transportation networks to enhance system service reliability. Research from this project opens up a new field of research on planning sustainable and resilient engineering infrastructure facilities under the threat of disruptive hazards, which can be applied to problems in more general contexts such as planning energy and lifeline infrastructure systems. Building upon these fundamental understandings, information strategies that stabilize car-following traffic as well as nonlinear supply chains are designed and tested on unstructured interactive simulation platforms such as the “ADI supply chain game” and the “driving-in-queue game” (also developed as part of this project). The theoretical results from this project are not only verified by simulations, but also validated with field data.  

Through wide dissemination of research outcomes (e.g., over 30 peer reviewed journal papers published or under review, over 60 invited or conference presentations, and two software platforms), this research project has provided fundamental insights and practical management/control strategies that are suitable for stabilizing and improving operations of a variety of transportation networks. The outcomes are expected to have a profound impact on the transportation and freight logistics industry, with strong economical and societal implications (e.g., reducing congestion and resource consumption). The new integrated analysis framework created through this project has opened up a new research direction toward solutions to a wide range of complex problems in diverse scientific fields. For example, our work has shed light on new traffic control strategies that will mitigate the prevailing traffic oscillation phenomenon as well as its adverse impacts (e.g., extra resource consumption, severe air pollution, safety hazard, driver discomfort).   This project also has led to new educational practices by the creation, integration, and dissemination of a series of innovative teaching materials such as Internet-based interactive simulation tools (e.g., the “ADI supply chain game” and the “driving-in-queue game”).  These games have been integrated into the PI’s regular teaching efforts at the University of Illinois, to enhance hands-on experience and overall learning effectiveness of the students.
